title: Energy conservation - pt charge moves from A to B

content.question: An electric field in a region of space has a nonuniform magnitude, as depicted by the electric field map in the figure. A positive point charge (not shown) already in motion at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, moves due to the field alone to Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. As the point charge moves from Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> to Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, its kinetic energy increases by an amount <math alttext="delta K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>K</mi></math>, while the electric potential energy of the point charge-field system decreases by an amount <math alttext="the absolute value of delta U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>|</mo><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>U</mi><mo>|</mo></math>. Are <math alttext="delta K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>K</mi></math> and <math alttext="the absolute value of delta U" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>|</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>U</mi><mo>|</mo></math> equal to one another? What evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: Yes. The total energy of the system remains constant in the absence of external forces.

Yes. The point charge’s speed increases as it moves from Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> to Point <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>.
No. The point charge is already moving at Point <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, rather than starting from rest.

No. The electric field magnitude changes between points <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, rather than being uniform.

content.answer: Yes. The total energy of the system remains constant in the absence of external forces.
